ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Unfortunately I don't think I learned too much. The course was very surface level and although we encountered many general concepts, I would not say I got very much out of it.
I learned more about the standard model, experimentation methods in nuclear and particle physics, and an overview of a Lagrangian treatment of the standard model.
I learned very little in this class. I can't say I developed any insight.

A good intro to various topics in particle physics, including elementary particles, experimental methods, Feynman diagrams, and modern topics. Application of some quantum mechanics principles, practice with conservation laws, and thorough review of relativistic kinematics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The primary strength is Prof. Baker. He is genuinely such a nice guy and always very helpful and accomodating. However, the lectures themselves left a lot to be desired.

Our class was not given a teaching fellow, which made organizing help sessions difficult. This course could be improved with a teaching fellow. Also, more structure in the planning of the course. It felt like we switched between undergraduate and graduate material several points during the semester, and I think it would be more helpful if one approach were taken.

This course was poorly designed and barely cohesive. Most lectures seemed to connect only loosely to the next. I think if the course were deliberately mapped out in advance, this would aid significantly in the cohesion of the course. If this did occur, we could not tell.

I think this course would be best taken when it isn't cross-listed, i.e. when it's either 442 OR 526 but not both. Both the undergrad and grad-level topics were super interesting but I think they each deserve their own course. That being said, one of the strengths of this course was the way it was able to treat topics at increasing levels of difficulty so we could see various applications of what we were learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you want a low workload physics elective thats a free A/A-, then go ahead.
It gives a very broad overview of the material of nuclear and particle physics but you leave feeling like you didn't learn much.

I would not recommend this course to a friend. I don't think this was a good use of my time. I didn't learn much at all and any engagement I had with the course felt like busywork. Lectures were not designed well. Problem sets were not helpful. Questions in class were not answered. If the only difference between going to class and skipping and just reading the lecture notes later is the ability to have your questions about the content answered, I just don't think one can justify going to this class.
Yes, definitely! Especially if you're interested in particle physics, but it's accessible to anyone in the major.
